text: @joel I just read Luke's email. Can't think of what causing this issue. Maybe we could ask him to open Chrome's dev tools and send us a screenshot of the any errors in there.
I'm stumped as well. I did ask him to refresh the window, figuring he didn't since he kicked the server.
And yes, agree that a grab of the dev tools output would be helpful
just had him do a clean uninstall/reinstall
yeah it sounds like he's just not refreshing the browser to me... but i guess he is
Cool. Will keep an eye on the BC messages and will jump in if he keeps having UI issues.
found the problem - main.js was still pointing to 10.1.10.19. Fixed on his rig, and will update in the package.
nice one <@U02E3CRMA>. have we eradicated all the 10.1.10.19s?
looks like it. grepped the whole tree, and the only ones were in main.js/scripts.min.js
OH, my bad. Thanks for helping out with this one.

<@U02E3CRMA> About that latest email from Luke, do you know if he's comfortable with the browser dev tools? I can just ask him to type the one function in there instead of adding the click functionality to dismiss the welcome screen.
let me see if I can clean things up on his config before we make any changes
he messed with the camera height and configuration, so I have no idea what we're dealing with right now
Thanks. Just talked to Evans and the other thing we could do is have a dev version of the .html and .js code that with the UI devmode on.
Would it be easy for you to create a second Chromium button that opens on the dev html file?

Yes, very easy. What if you took an inline param to the js file that enabled dev mode? Then i can create a second icon that passes that URL. For instance file:///usr/local/luxo/ui/index.html?debug=true
Sure. Already had that :simple_smile:
Just set devMode to true
Oh, wait, don't think I had it wired up to the URL param
let me check
excellent
<@U02E3CRMA> Just pushed the code. Adding ?devMode=true to the url should now turn dev mode on.
Have to leave now but will be on slack and will be back online in 30 mins.
Thanks, Gaston. I'll get this all packaged up and sent over on Monday AM. Between setting up the cam and getting a new calibration, I think Luke's got plenty to do for now.
vidId and hwId: /dev/video0, 1
oh hi jenny!
it said that before he plugged the mic in
hi
i'm guessing he tried recording after plugging the mic in...
oh thats the last avconv output from the log he just posted
lemme check it out i haven't looked yet
cool cool
thank you, btw!
okay yeah it's at the bottom of the log so i'm guessing he did try to record after plugging the mic in
would it be helpful to have him run the probe command and send the output to you
mmm that bash script pretty much just outputs what we're seeing in the logs
what about maybe running the avconv recording command by hand and seeing THAT output?
since now you know the variables

yeah. he should restart it after plugging in the mic if he hasn't already though. after that i can't imagine what the problem is unless the device names i'm grep - ing for in the bash script are different since he's using different hardware...
i mean on his end
oh its possible
...yeah
can you send the probe command that the bash script runs, and the avconv command
yeah
and get him to post the results?
and i'll tell him to restart if he hasn't
SHERLOCK HOLMES
sweet thank you.
woulda been nice if this had come up ~8 hours ago
I agree. If you point me at a file in the repo, i can orchestrate it as best i can and leave you alone!
nah it's fine i'm curious now.
i'll write up directions for him in basecamp
#cats
thanks. I'm gonna eat some dinner for a minute, but i'll be nearby
kk
<@U026PHQ3J> what's the command to list the details of the video devices in /dev ?
I don't remember offhand
It's in the bash script
(Sorry I literally just closed my laptop)
yeah, i'm having trouble coming up with a one-liner for him
Ok one sec
thanks!
ooh i see
oh wait
looks like
arecord -l
that's audio devices
right
do we care about video devices?
cause you could tell him to get you the output of this:
udevadm info --name=/dev/video0 && udevadm info --name=/dev/video1
oo okay yeah
i just want to cover all our bases since you said that he's not using the same camera as us
and that bash script was written specifically for what we have
right. i think its the same model, but a different firmware rev.
agree.
good call
in fact, send him this:
udevadm info --name=/dev/video0 && udevadm info --name=/dev/video1 && arecord -l
k
it'll be a lot of output but it will get everything in one line
is the camera always video0 and video1?
I think so
